initial_access_vector.technique_name: Phishing for Slack SSO/cloud credentials followed by login

method_steps.description: The attacker sends targeted phishing messages (for example, via email) that imitate Slack login prompts or SSO notifications, luring users to a fake sign-in page designed to capture Slack or IdP credentials.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: User-facing sign-in experience for Slack clients and SSO, as governed by admin authentication settings – https://slack.com/enterprise/
Branding and login flows implied by the Authentication overview – https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/
related_data: Usernames/emails and passwords for Slack or IdP accounts
Potential MFA codes if the phishing page also requests second factors
method_steps.notes: The phishing infrastructure is external, but it is explicitly themed around Slack’s SSO and login behaviour to harvest Slack-relevant credentials.

method_steps.description: Once the victim submits credentials (and possibly MFA codes) to the phishing site, the attacker uses those stolen credentials to authenticate to Slack’s legitimate sign-in flows and establish a session, as described in the Cloud Accounts vector.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: SSO integration with the IdP – https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/
related_data: Stolen credentials reused against real Slack or IdP login endpoints
New Slack session cookies and authentication tokens bound to the victim user
method_steps.notes: From Slack’s perspective, this appears as a normal interactive login from the victim’s account; the credential theft itself is handled in the phishing infrastructure.

capabilities_used: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
interfaces_used: Admin-configured SSO and MFA flows – https://slack.com/enterprise/
Authentication documentation (used indirectly to craft realistic phishing lures) – https://docs.slack.dev/authentication/
data_accessed: Slack or IdP credentials and possibly MFA factors harvested via phishing (before use against Slack)
All Slack data visible to the compromised account once the attacker logs in (channels, DMs, files, canvases, lists, search results)
preconditions_required: The attacker can reliably reach target users via email or other channels to send phishing messages.
Victims do not consistently verify Slack/SSO URLs and may be tricked into entering credentials into a look-alike page.
If MFA Required is enforced, the phishing infrastructure must capture or bypass MFA as part of the phish (for example, man-in-the-middle of SSO).
constraints_encountered: MFA Required significantly raises the bar for successful credential phishing; attackers must capture MFA in real time or steal session tokens instead.
SSO-Only Authentication means phishing must target the IdP login experience rather than any legacy Slack username/password flow.
Rate Limiting and CAPTCHA Protection on login endpoints make automated credential-stuffing style phishing reuse more difficult but do not prevent single successful logins.
evasion_considerations: Use domains and TLS certificates that closely resemble legitimate Slack or IdP domains to defeat superficial URL checks.
Time the use of stolen credentials so that logins occur soon after phishing, matching expected user behaviour and reducing risk of password changes.
If possible, reuse victims’ typical IP ranges via compromised endpoints to blend into IP-based anomaly detection.
initial_access_vector.resulting_access: An authenticated Slack session under a legitimate user or admin account, obtained by phishing credentials and then logging in through Slack’s normal authentication flows.
initial_access_vector.comments: Although credential theft is a separate tactic, this vector represents a common Initial Access pattern in SaaS environments: phishing specifically for SSO/Slack credentials and immediately using them to authenticate to Slack.

method_steps.description: Using the authenticated Slack session obtained via phishing, the attacker opens the Slack desktop or web client for the compromised workspace and confirms they are fully logged in as the victim user.
related_interfaces: Slack desktop and web client – channel list, message composer, threads, reactions, pins. – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: workspace_id
user_id associated with the compromised account

method_steps.description: The attacker browses the channel list and any "channel browser" or sidebar navigation to enumerate all public channels they can see, noting channel names, topics, and approximate membership counts to infer team and project structures.
related_interfaces: Slack desktop/web channel list and channel details – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: channel_id
channel name and topic
approximate member counts
method_steps.notes: Channel names and topics often encode team names, project codenames, or customer identifiers that help map the organization.

method_steps.description: Within each accessible channel, the attacker opens the member list or channel details pane to enumerate the users in that channel, recording display names and visible profile snippets for later correlation.
related_interfaces: Channel member list in Slack clients – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: user_id for channel members
display names and avatars
method_steps.notes: Large default channels (e.g., company-wide announcements) maximize coverage of the user base.

method_steps.description: The attacker starts a new direct message or multi-person DM and uses the recipient auto-complete to scroll through and search for users, capturing additional user accounts that may not yet appear in shared channels.
related_interfaces: Direct Messages list and new DM composer – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: dm_conversation_id (for any started DMs)
user_id suggestions returned by auto-complete
method_steps.notes: Auto-complete can reveal many valid account names even if the attacker never sends messages to them.

method_steps.description: Using Slack’s search box, the attacker searches for common corporate email domains, org-wide distribution list names, or generic role terms (for example, “@example.com”, “CISO”, “HR”) to surface messages that mention or tag additional users, then inspects the associated profiles.
related_capabilities: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
related_interfaces: Search UI in Slack clients and enterprise search – https://slack.com/enterprise/
related_data: search queries
message text and mentions containing email addresses or role references
file metadata and link previews that may include author names
method_steps.notes: Search is used here to extend account discovery, not to harvest specific secrets.

method_steps.description: For each discovered user, the attacker opens the user’s profile card from messages or member lists to collect visible attributes such as email address, job title, department, manager, timezone, and custom profile fields.
related_interfaces: User profile popovers/pages within Slack clients – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: user_id
email address (if visible)
job title and department
custom profile fields (e.g., location, phone)
method_steps.notes: Profile attributes help identify admins, executives, security staff, and high-value business roles.

interfaces_used: Slack desktop and web client – channel list, message composer, threads, reactions, pins. – https://slack.com/team-chat/
Slack clients search box and enterprise search UI – https://slack.com/enterprise/
Messages surface for browsing messages and member lists – https://docs.slack.dev/surfaces/#messages
data_accessed: workspace_id
user_id values for many workspace members
channel_id and basic channel metadata (name, topic, member count)
dm_conversation_id for initiated DMs
user profile attributes (email, title, department, manager, custom fields)
search queries and search result snippets
preconditions_required: Compromised account must be an active member of at least one workspace in the Slack org.
Org configuration must allow the user to see channel member lists and user profiles (normal for standard members).
evasion_considerations: Perform enumeration gradually during normal working hours to blend with legitimate activity.
Avoid opening hundreds of profiles in rapid succession to reduce the chance of triggering anomalous client behavior or support tickets.
Prefer UI-based exploration over direct Web API scripting to stay within typical user traffic patterns.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: A broad, but user-scoped, directory of Slack accounts in the compromised workspace, including user identifiers, display names, email addresses (where visible), job titles, departments, and the set of channels in which those users participate.

method_steps.description: Using the authenticated session from the initial compromise, the attacker inspects the sidebar and channel browser to list all channels and any visible distinctions between public, private, and Slack Connect (externally shared) channels.
related_interfaces: Slack desktop/web channel list and channel browser – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: channel_id
channel type (public/private/Slack Connect, as indicated in the UI)
workspace_id

method_steps.description: The attacker joins as many public channels as possible to increase visibility, then opens each channel’s details pane to enumerate members, owners, and any visible roles (for example, channel admins or designated leads).
related_interfaces: Channel details and member list UI – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: channel_id
user_id for channel members
any role labels exposed in channel metadata
method_steps.notes: Channel-level membership acts as an implicit permission group for access to messages and files in that channel.

method_steps.description: The attacker uses channel names, topics, and descriptions (for example, channels prefixed with security-, exec-, finance-) to infer functional permission groups (security team, executives, finance) and to identify channels they cannot join but can still see listed, indicating additional restricted groups.
related_interfaces: Channel browser and search UI – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: channel names and topics
whether the compromised user can join or is restricted from specific channels
method_steps.notes: The existence of visible-but-locked channels reveals high-sensitivity teams and projects even without content access.

method_steps.description: The attacker examines their own account’s role and permissions (for example, whether they appear as a workspace admin, owner, or guest) via account settings and any visible admin menus to understand their current privilege tier relative to others.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: Slack account/settings and workspace administration menus – https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103
related_data: role of compromised user (member, admin, owner, guest)
workspace-level capability flags (ability to manage channels, apps, members)
method_steps.notes: Confirming whether the compromised account is an admin or owner directly affects what further discovery vectors are possible.

method_steps.description: If the compromised user can see user group constructs (such as functional groups used for mentions or announcements), the attacker enumerates those groups and their members by observing mentions (for example, @managers, @security-team) and any available group-management UI.
related_data: logical group names (for example, @managers)
user_ids associated with those groups as inferred from messages or group views
method_steps.notes: Slack user groups (where used) map closely to internal functional and permission groupings.

capabilities_used: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
interfaces_used: Slack desktop and web channel list and browser – https://slack.com/team-chat/
Channel details and member list UI – https://slack.com/team-chat/
data_accessed: channel_id and channel type (public/private/Slack Connect)
membership lists for channels the compromised user can access
names and topics of visible-but-locked channels
role of the compromised account (member/admin/owner/guest)
logical group identifiers inferred from mentions (for example, manager groups)
preconditions_required: Compromised account must be able to view the workspace’s channel list and channel details (standard behavior for regular members).
evasion_considerations: Pace channel joining and browsing to avoid suspicious spikes in join/leave events.
Avoid attempting to join obviously restricted or executive channels in rapid succession, which could attract attention from admins.
Use existing channel participation rather than mass-joining as much as possible to infer group structures.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: A map of effective permission groups in the workspace based on channels, membership lists, visible-but-restricted channels, and any user group constructs, plus confirmation of the compromised account’s own role and capabilities.

method_steps.description: From the compromised user’s Slack client, the attacker scans the channel list for channels marked as Slack Connect or otherwise visually indicated as shared with external organizations.
related_interfaces: Slack Connect shared channel indicators in the Slack client – https://slack.com/connect/
related_data: shared_channel_id (internally associated with shared channels)
channel name and topic

method_steps.description: For each Slack Connect channel the attacker can access, they open the channel details pane to view information about participating external organizations (for example, partner organization names and member lists).
related_interfaces: Slack Connect channel details UI – https://slack.com/connect/
related_data: names of external organizations collaborating in each shared channel
user_ids belonging to external participants in those channels
method_steps.notes: Even if raw workspace_ids are not exposed in the UI, organization names and branding are sufficient to identify partners.

method_steps.description: The attacker reviews any direct messages that are flagged as external (for example, DMs with external guests or cross-org contacts) to identify one-to-one trust relationships and partner representatives.
related_interfaces: External DM and Slack Connect DM UI – https://slack.com/connect/
DM list under Direct Messages – https://slack.com/team-chat/
related_data: dm_conversation_id for external DMs
user_ids and profile data for external participants

method_steps.description: If permitted by workspace policy, the attacker initiates the workflow to create a new Slack Connect shared channel or external DM and inspects any intermediate screens for hints about approved or disallowed external domains and organizations before cancelling the operation.
related_interfaces: Slack Connect channel/DM creation flows – https://slack.com/connect/
related_data: list of organizations or domains presented as selectable or blocked (if surfaced in the UI)
policy messages describing who can create Slack Connect channels and under what conditions
method_steps.notes: Admin Approval Required for Slack Connect invitations may restrict actual channel creation, but simple exploration of the wizard can still leak policy and trust information.

interfaces_used: Slack Connect shared channel and DM UI – https://slack.com/connect/
Slack desktop/web channel and DM lists – https://slack.com/team-chat/
data_accessed: names of external organizations participating in shared channels and DMs
identities of external participants (user_ids and profiles)
classification of channels as internal-only vs Slack Connect
high-level Slack Connect policy messages or hints shown in end-user flows
preconditions_required: Slack Connect must be enabled for the target workspace or organization.
The compromised account must be a member of at least one Slack Connect channel or DM, or be allowed to initiate Slack Connect flows.
constraints_encountered: Admin Approval Required for Slack Connect invitations may prevent creation of new shared channels purely for reconnaissance, limiting the attacker to already-existing connections and any policy hints shown in the UI.

IP Allowlisting, if configured for the org, requires the attacker to operate from allowlisted IP ranges (for example, by using the victim’s device) to access Slack at all, including Slack Connect views.
evasion_considerations: Limit actions to viewing existing Slack Connect channels and DMs rather than repeatedly initiating failed external invitations.
Avoid mass-creating or attempting to create Slack Connect channels, which could generate alerts or admin approval requests.
Blend any Slack Connect exploration into normal collaboration patterns (for example, joining relevant project channels before inspecting their external participants).
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: A map of which external organizations and users have trusted access to the Slack environment via Slack Connect shared channels and DMs, revealing cross-tenant trust relationships and likely business partnerships.

method_steps.description: From the compromised user’s Slack client, the attacker opens the in-client app directory or "Apps" section to view the list of apps that are installed and available in the current workspace.
related_interfaces: Slack in-client app directory / Apps section – https://slack.com/marketplace/
related_data: app identifiers and names for installed apps
basic app metadata (category, short description)

method_steps.description: The attacker inspects channels and DMs for bot messages, app cards, and AI agent responses, identifying which third-party tools (for example, Google Drive, Salesforce, Asana) and internal bots are actively posting content.
related_capabilities: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
Agentforce and AI agents in Slack
App surfaces and Block Kit UI framework
related_interfaces: Messages surface where app messages and cards appear – https://docs.slack.dev/surfaces/#messages
Slack Agentforce and AI agents interface – https://slack.com/ai-agents/
related_data: user_id values for bot and agent accounts
file and link metadata included in app cards (for example, document titles, CRM records)
method_steps.notes: App-branded messages and cards clearly indicate which integrations are in use, even without admin access.

method_steps.description: The attacker triggers or inspects global and message shortcuts, slash commands, and interactive Block Kit elements (buttons, menus) to enumerate available app-driven workflows and understand what actions each app can perform.
related_capabilities: Interactivity: shortcuts, slash commands, and interactive components
App surfaces and Block Kit UI framework
related_interfaces: Interactivity (shortcuts, slash commands, interactive components) – https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/
related_data: slash command names and associated apps
shortcut identifiers and action_ids indicating app workflows
method_steps.notes: The visible set of commands and shortcuts provides a concise inventory of installed apps and their intended capabilities.

method_steps.description: If the attacker can access the Slack Marketplace or a "Manage apps" page in the client, they switches to views that show which apps are already installed in the workspace and inspects each listing for requested scopes and integration details.
related_data: installed app list for the workspace
app metadata including permissions requested and connected external services
method_steps.notes: Even without admin rights, many workspaces allow members to see at least a partial list of installed apps.

method_steps.description: The attacker observes any AI agents (including Agentforce-based agents) that are present in channels or DMs, notes their names and described capabilities, and optionally interacts with them to infer which enterprise systems (for example, CRM, data cloud) they can access.
related_capabilities: Agentforce and AI agents in Slack
Slack AI for summaries and assistance
related_interfaces: Agentforce and AI agents overview – https://slack.com/ai-agents/
related_data: names and roles of configured AI agents
types of questions they can answer and systems they reference in responses
method_steps.notes: AI agents often reveal in their prompts or responses which back-end systems (CRM, data warehouse, ticketing) they can reach, aiding broader cloud service discovery.

capabilities_used: File sharing and contextual document collaboration
Agentforce and AI agents in Slack
App surfaces and Block Kit UI framework
Interactivity: shortcuts, slash commands, and interactive components
Slack AI for summaries and assistance
interfaces_used: Slack in-client app directory / Apps section – https://slack.com/marketplace/
Slack Marketplace and app listing pages – https://slack.com/marketplace/
Agentforce and AI agents overview – https://slack.com/ai-agents/
data_accessed: list of installed apps, bots, and AI agents in the workspace
app metadata such as descriptions, categories, and (where visible) requested OAuth scopes
visible slash commands, shortcuts, and interactive workflows tied to specific apps
channel history showing bot and agent messages, including which external systems they reference
basic indications of which external SaaS systems (for example, Google Drive, Salesforce, Jira) are integrated via Slack apps
preconditions_required: The compromised user must be allowed by workspace policy to view the app directory or at least the list of apps installed in channels they can access.
Some organizations may restrict Marketplace browsing or app installation; even then, messages from already-installed apps are still discoverable in channels.
constraints_encountered: App installation or deeper configuration changes may require Admin Approval Required, but simple discovery of existing apps via the UI does not.
IP Allowlisting, if configured, requires the attacker to operate from permit‑listed IP ranges to access Slack and the app directory.
evasion_considerations: Prefer passive observation of app activity and existing app lists over requesting new app installs, which could trigger approval workflows and scrutiny.
Interact with AI agents and bots in the context of legitimate-looking questions to avoid raising suspicion.
Avoid issuing high volumes of slash commands or shortcut invocations in a short time window, which might look automated.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: An inventory of third-party and internal apps, bots, and AI agents installed in the workspace, including their rough capabilities and the external systems they integrate with, enabling the attacker to understand the broader SaaS footprint connected to Slack.

discovery_vectors.technique_name: Cloud Groups (Org-wide permission groups via admin & SCIM APIs)

method_steps.description: Using the compromised session, the attacker checks whether the account has workspace or org admin privileges by looking for admin menus (for example, "Administration" or "Organization settings") in the Slack UI.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_data: whether the compromised user is an admin, owner, or org-level admin
method_steps.notes: This step determines whether elevated, org-wide discovery via admin and SCIM APIs is possible.

method_steps.description: If the account is a workspace or org admin, the attacker opens the member management pages in the admin console to list all users, their roles (member, owner, admin, guest), and any visible status information (for example, deactivated users).
related_data: full list of user_id values for the workspace or org
role flags (workspace admin, owner, org admin, guest)
basic profile attributes surfaced in admin views
method_steps.notes: This provides a coarse-grained view of permission groups based on Slack’s built-in roles.

method_steps.description: For Enterprise organizations, the attacker navigates to org-level administration views to enumerate all workspaces in the org and to see how users are segmented across those workspaces (for example, which users are in which workspaces by default).
related_interfaces: Enterprise Grid / Enterprise+ org admin UI – https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103
related_data: enterprise_id
workspace_id list
mapping of users to workspaces
method_steps.notes: Workspace segmentation often reflects business units or geographic regions and thus acts as another layer of grouping.

method_steps.description: If SCIM provisioning is enabled, the attacker (as org admin) uses the admin UI to obtain or configure SCIM API access, then uses an external script or tool to call Slack’s SCIM endpoints to list all users and groups, including group memberships and any role-related attributes.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: SCIM API documentation and endpoints – https://docs.slack.dev/admins/scim-api/
related_data: SCIM user objects with profile attributes and active/deprovisioned status
SCIM group objects and membership lists (functional groups, security groups)
method_steps.notes: SCIM groups often mirror IdP or HR group structures, giving a high-fidelity view of organizational and permission groupings.

method_steps.description: Where available, the attacker leverages any existing admin-focused apps or creates an internal admin app (subject to existing policies) with admin.* scopes to call Admin APIs (for example, to list users, channels, and memberships) and build a machine-readable graph of permission relationships across the org.
related_capabilities: OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
App distribution and Slack Marketplace listing
related_data: organization-wide user and channel data from Admin APIs
OAuth tokens with admin.* scopes enabling programmatic enumeration
method_steps.notes: Rate Limiting on admin endpoints requires low-and-slow enumeration and careful handling of pagination.

method_steps.description: The attacker correlates role information from admin UIs, SCIM groups, and Admin API responses to identify high-privilege subsets (org owners, workspace admins, security groups), privileged service accounts, and any misconfigured groups with excessive rights.
related_interfaces: Admin UI and Admin API documentation – https://slack.com/help/categories/200122103 , https://docs.slack.dev/admins/
related_data: lists of users with high-privilege roles
SCIM and Slack groups that include privileged users
workspace and channel mappings for those users

capabilities_used: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
OAuth-based authentication and tokens for apps
App distribution and Slack Marketplace listing
data_accessed: complete lists of users across the workspace or Enterprise org
role and permission flags for each user (member, admin, owner, guest)
workspace segmentation and default channel memberships
SCIM user and group objects and group memberships
Admin API outputs listing users, channels, and membership relationships
OAuth tokens and scopes associated with admin-facing apps (if created or reused)
preconditions_required: The compromised account must be a workspace or org admin (or owner) to access admin consoles and configure SCIM or admin apps.
The organization must be on a paid plan that exposes Admin APIs and, if applicable, SCIM provisioning.
If SCIM or Admin APIs are used programmatically, the attacker must be able to execute code or tools from an environment within any IP Allowlisting constraints.
constraints_encountered: Rate Limiting applies to Admin and SCIM API calls, requiring careful pagination and low request rates to avoid throttling or errors.
IP Allowlisting, if enforced for the Slack org, constrains where API calls and admin UI access can originate, pushing the attacker to operate from the victim’s network or device.
Admin Approval Required for new internal apps can limit the attacker’s ability to create fresh admin-scoped apps; they may need to rely on existing admin apps or purely on the admin UI.
evasion_considerations: Favor admin UI exports and occasional API queries over sustained, high-volume enumeration to stay within normal admin behavior patterns.
If creating or modifying apps, choose innocuous names and descriptions that fit existing internal patterns.
Schedule heavy enumeration tasks during maintenance windows or off-hours when admin activity is less scrutinized.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: A comprehensive, organization-wide directory of users, groups, and roles—including SCIM groups, workspace segmentation, and admin-level permissions—sufficient to identify all high-privilege accounts and major functional groupings in the Slack tenant.

discovery_vectors.technique_name: Software Discovery (Org-wide apps and integrations via governance & audit)

method_steps.description: With an admin-capable compromised account, the attacker opens the app management and governance sections of the Slack admin console to view the full list of apps installed across the workspace or Enterprise org, including internal and Marketplace apps.
related_interfaces: Admin guides for managing app approvals – https://docs.slack.dev/admins/managing-app-approvals
related_data: organization-wide list of app identifiers and names
installation status and approval decisions per app

method_steps.description: The attacker inspects details for each app where available (for example, requested OAuth scopes, installation count, which workspaces it is installed to), using this to infer which external systems each app connects to and how broadly it is deployed.
related_data: requested OAuth scopes for each app (where visible)
workspace_ids or installation contexts for each app
categories and descriptions for installed apps
method_steps.notes: Scopes and descriptions often explicitly reference back-end systems (for example, CRM, code repositories, ticketing).

method_steps.description: If the attacker has access to the Audit Logs API, they queries for events related to app installation, removal, and scope changes over an extended time window to build a historical picture of which apps have been used and where.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
related_data: audit events of types related to apps (install, uninstall, scope changes)
timestamps, actor identities, and target apps from audit records
method_steps.notes: This reveals which apps were trialed or removed, not just currently active ones.

method_steps.description: The attacker correlates app installation data with channel history by searching for each app’s bot user or message patterns, identifying which teams and channels actively use each integration and how critical they may be.
related_data: channels where each app or bot posts messages
frequency and recency of app activity per channel

capabilities_used: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
interfaces_used: Admin app approval APIs and docs – https://docs.slack.dev/admins/managing-app-approvals
Messages surface and search UI – https://docs.slack.dev/surfaces/#messages , https://slack.com/enterprise/
data_accessed: complete list of installed apps and integrations across the org
per-app installation scope (which workspaces/orgs) and approval state
requested OAuth scopes indicating data access breadth for each app
audit events relating to app lifecycle and configuration changes
channel- and team-level usage patterns of specific apps and bots
preconditions_required: Compromised account must have admin privileges to access app governance UIs and potentially Audit Logs API.
Organization must be on a plan that exposes app governance and Audit Logs features (typically Enterprise-tier).
constraints_encountered: Rate Limiting applies to Audit Logs API queries; the attacker must paginate and throttle requests to avoid throttling or errors.
IP Allowlisting constrains from where admin APIs and consoles can be accessed; enumeration must originate from allowed IP ranges.
Admin Approval Required for installing new apps limits the attacker’s ability to deploy additional reconnaissance apps, though it does not prevent them from inventorying existing apps.
evasion_considerations: Use coarse time windows and minimal filters when querying Audit Logs to reduce API call volume.
Review existing app governance dashboards and reports instead of exporting or querying excessively.
Blend app-management browsing into normal admin maintenance activities and avoid sudden mass configuration changes.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: A detailed inventory of all apps and integrations deployed across the Slack environment, including internal tools and third-party SaaS connectors, their scopes, deployment breadth, and historical usage, enabling the attacker to understand the wider software and service ecosystem linked to Slack.

method_steps.description: With org- or workspace-admin access, the attacker navigates to the Slack Connect governance settings to view configured policies, including which external domains and organizations are allowed or blocked for Slack Connect.

internal channel names linked to each shared channel
names or identifiers of connected external workspaces

actors initiating or approving external connections
identifiers for external workspaces and domains involved

interfaces_used: Slack Connect security and governance resources – https://slack.com/resources/slack-for-admins/slack-connect-security

summary: From a phished Slack SSO session, an attacker can perform extensive discovery without leaving normal product surfaces. At the user level, they can enumerate accounts, channels, and implicit permission groups, identify Slack Connect shared channels and external partners, and inventory visible apps, bots, and AI agents. If the compromised account has admin or owner privileges in a paid or Enterprise-tier tenant, the attacker’s visibility expands substantially: they can use admin consoles, Admin and SCIM APIs, and Audit Logs/Legal Holds to build complete maps of users, roles, groups, workspaces, apps, workflows, and Slack Connect trust relationships, as well as to understand security, retention, export, EKM, data residency, and authentication/MFA policies. Public status and trust documentation further reveal Slack’s underlying cloud services and operational model. Environment constraints like MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, Admin Approval Required, IP Allowlisting, and Rate Limiting do little to impede post-compromise discovery, but they influence how stealthily the attacker must perform API-based enumeration and may limit where those API calls can originate.

Security monitoring via Audit Logs API or third-party tools might detect sudden changes in an app’s behaviour (new endpoints contacted, unusual API usage patterns).
If customers aggressively scope apps to least privilege and avoid granting admin-level scopes, the impact of a compromised app is limited, even if initial access is achieved.

preconditions_required: The compromised app must have valid OAuth tokens for the target tenant (satisfied by the initial access vector).
To use Web API user listing endpoints, the app needs user-identity read scopes as granted during initial installation.
To use the SCIM API, the tenant must be on an Enterprise plan and the app must have been granted SCIM-related scopes.
To access the Audit Logs API, the app must hold appropriate audit/admin scopes and the tenant must have enabled the Audit Logs feature.
To receive Events API payloads, the app must already be subscribed to relevant events and configured with functioning event delivery (HTTPS or Socket Mode).
constraints_encountered: Rate Limiting – Slack’s Web API, SCIM API, and Audit Logs API are rate-limited; bulk enumeration must be throttled and paginated to avoid hitting limits or generating anomalous spikes in traffic.

IP Allowlisting – If the customer restricts Slack app traffic to specific IP ranges (e.g., via egress controls or app-allowlisting proxies), enumeration must be performed from the same vendor infrastructure already used by the app so that calls appear normal; new infrastructure may be blocked outright.

MFA Required / SSO-Only Authentication / Domain-Based Registration / CAPTCHA / Email Verification / Admin Approval – These primarily affect user sign-in and app installation; they do not directly constrain enumeration via already-issued OAuth tokens, but they may make it harder for the attacker to obtain *additional* user tokens or apps if they attempt to expand beyond the compromised integration.
Admin Approval Required – Prevents the attacker from trivially deploying new, more-privileged apps, increasing reliance on whatever scopes the compromised integration already holds.
evasion_considerations: Prefer incremental enumeration (e.g., caching previous results and only querying deltas) instead of frequent full-tenant `list` operations to blend into normal app behavior and stay under rate limits.
Schedule heavy enumeration tasks during times when the legitimate app historically performs maintenance or synchronization to avoid creating new patterns in audit and SIEM data.
Rely on passive discovery through Events API streams where available, reducing the volume of explicit Web/SCIM API calls.
Avoid changing app scopes or installing new instances, which would trigger fresh consent prompts or admin reviews and increase the chance of detection.

constraints_encountered: Slack’s public platform and admin documentation in the analyzed corpus do not expose any API or app-accessible endpoint for retrieving workspace/org password complexity or lockout policies; password behavior is largely controlled by Slack globally or by external IdPs when SSO is configured.

The compromised app’s access is via OAuth tokens, not via user interactive sessions or OS-level command shells, so it cannot run host-level utilities (such as `net accounts`) or IdP-specific cmdlets that MITRE examples reference for password policy discovery.

Authentication and access control capabilities for Slack (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM) are administered through Slack’s admin UI and external identity providers; there is no documented mechanism for a Slack app token to query password policies directly from those systems.

Environment constraints such as MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, and Domain-Based Registration actually *strengthen* credential protections but do not create new app-visible APIs that would allow the attacker to enumerate detailed password policies from within Slack.

discovery_vectors.comments: While MITRE’s Password Policy Discovery technique is relevant in many on-prem and IaaS contexts, the analyzed Slack capabilities do not provide an app-accessible interface to password policy configuration. The compromised Slack app operates solely with OAuth tokens and cannot query or infer detailed password rules (e.g., length, complexity, lockout thresholds) beyond generic knowledge that SSO or 2FA may be enforced.

constraints_encountered: The attacker’s foothold is purely programmatic via a compromised Slack app’s OAuth tokens; there is no indication that the attacker has stolen interactive user credentials capable of logging into the Slack web or admin UI (the cloud service dashboard in this context).

Slack’s admin and configuration surfaces described in the ApplicationCapabilityAnalysis are GUI- and human-focused; there is no documented feature that allows an app token to open or drive an admin dashboard session on behalf of a user, beyond normal API calls already covered under Cloud Service Discovery.

Environment constraints like MFA Required, SSO-Only Authentication, and Admin Approval Required make it even harder for an attacker to obtain or abuse interactive admin sessions without additional compromise of human identities or IdPs—steps that go beyond the assumed initial access via supply-chain compromise of an app.

Any attempt to coerce admins into visiting attacker-controlled dashboards or links (for example, via phishing messages from the app) would move into social engineering and other tactics outside the Discovery scope defined for this analysis.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: Not achievable from the current starting point; without stolen interactive credentials or additional compromise paths, the attacker cannot directly leverage Slack’s admin GUI as a discovery surface beyond what is already exposed via APIs.
discovery_vectors.comments: MITRE’s Cloud Service Dashboard technique assumes access to a cloud provider’s GUI console. In this scenario, the attacker only controls a compromised Slack app and its OAuth tokens; there is no evidence of session hijacking or credential theft that would allow logging into Slack’s web/admin UI. All realistic discovery remains API-based and is already covered under the Cloud Service Discovery vector.

summary:
From the position of a compromised, already-trusted Slack app, the attacker can perform substantial Discovery using only documented APIs and features, without needing additional credentials or UI access. Concretely:

- **Cloud Account discovery** is achievable by enumerating Slack users via Web API user-listing methods, SCIM APIs (where granted), Audit Logs, and Events API streams. This yields a rich inventory of internal users, service accounts, guests, and external Slack Connect participants, along with basic roles and identity attributes.

- **Cloud Groups / permission structures** can be mapped by listing channels (including Slack Connect shared channels), retrieving membership for each, enumerating SCIM groups and admin/owner roles, and correlating this with Slack Connect metadata and audit events. The attacker can reconstruct who has access to which collaboration spaces and where cross-tenant trust boundaries exist.

- **Cloud Service discovery** is feasible by inspecting the app’s granted scopes and probing admin, governance, SCIM, workflow, marketplace, AI/agent, and status APIs. This reveals which Slack enterprise features (Audit Logs, Legal Holds, SCIM, AI agents, Workflow Builder, etc.) are enabled, which third-party and internal apps are installed, and how Slack is tied into the victim’s broader SaaS and identity ecosystem.

- **Password Policy Discovery** and **Cloud Service Dashboard** techniques are **not** directly achievable from this foothold: Slack does not expose password policies to apps, and the attacker lacks interactive user/admin credentials to exploit GUI dashboards. 

Environmental constraints such as MFA, SSO-only authentication, domain-based registration, CAPTCHA, and admin approval mainly harden initial access but do not prevent discovery via the already-issued OAuth tokens. The primary practical constraints on these discovery vectors are Slack’s API rate limits, potential IP allowlisting around the compromised vendor’s infrastructure, and the visibility created in customer audit logs and SIEMs when large-scale enumeration is attempted. By operating low-and-slow and blending into the legitimate app’s traffic patterns, a motivated attacker can nonetheless build a detailed picture of accounts, permission groups, and cloud services within the target Slack tenant from this initial access position.

summary:
From a foothold in a misconfigured Slack app’s Events/Interactivity endpoints, an attacker can realistically conduct several powerful Discovery techniques without ever holding a Slack user account. By forging slash-command and interactive payloads that the app fails to authenticate, and by impersonating high-privilege users in those payloads, the attacker can drive the app’s existing logic to:

• Enumerate Slack cloud accounts (Cloud Account) – abusing directory or admin-reporting features backed by the Web API, Admin APIs, and SCIM to obtain a near-complete list of users, bots, and service accounts plus role/profile metadata.

• Map permission groups and collaboration structure (Cloud Groups) – leveraging configuration modals and reports that list channels, user groups, and memberships to reconstruct which users belong to which channels and groups, including Slack Connect shared channels.

• Discover Slack service configuration and integration topology (Cloud Service Discovery) – invoking posture-style features that summarize plan tier, authentication and provisioning configuration, governance and compliance controls (retention, exports, legal holds, EKM), Slack Connect governance and tenant boundaries, and the inventory of installed apps and integrations.

• Learn detailed password and authentication policies (Password Policy Discovery) – where the compromised app is an AI/knowledge bot, using impersonated queries to have it read and summarize internal password and auth-policy documentation, revealing constraints that can guide future credential-focused activity.

Environment constraints around MFA, SSO-only authentication, and account registration do not significantly limit these vectors because the attacker operates entirely through app OAuth tokens and APIs, not through end-user logins. Rate limiting remains the main practical constraint, requiring low-and-slow enumeration patterns. The Cloud Service Dashboard technique is not achievable from this starting point, since it presumes the attacker can sign into Slack’s own web/admin dashboards with user credentials, which this initial access vector does not provide.

discovery_vectors.technique_name: Cloud Service Discovery via webhook trigger probing

method_steps.description: Using the exposed webhook or Deno Slack SDK webhook-trigger URL obtained during initial access, the attacker sends a minimal POST request with a simple, flat JSON body to confirm that the endpoint is live and associated with Slack.
related_capabilities: Developer tools: Slack CLI, Bolt frameworks, SDKs, and sandboxes
related_interfaces: Webhook triggers for Deno Slack SDK apps – linked from https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/
related_data: Webhook URL structure (https://hooks.slack.com/triggers/...)
HTTP status code and basic JSON response (e.g., {"ok":true} on success)
method_steps.notes: The Deno webhook trigger docs show that a successful invoke returns {"ok":true}; this lets the attacker positively confirm that the URL is an active Slack webhook trigger, not just a dead artifact.

method_steps.description: The attacker deliberately sends malformed or nested JSON in the POST body to elicit validation errors (for example, nested objects that Slack’s webhook triggers explicitly reject), observing the error codes or messages such as parameter_validation_failed returned in the HTTP response.
related_interfaces: Deno Slack SDK webhook trigger guide – https://docs.slack.dev/tools/deno-slack-sdk/guides/creating-webhook-triggers/#invoke-trigger
related_data: Error responses such as {"ok":false,"error":"parameter_validation_failed"} or equivalent JSON indicating validation failures
Implicit knowledge that the workflow expects only flat JSON payloads with specific keys
method_steps.notes: Docs state that nested JSON objects for webhook triggers return a parameter_validation_failed error. Being able to induce and observe that error confirms the endpoint is a Deno Slack SDK webhook trigger and reveals details of its validation behavior.

method_steps.description: By iteratively adjusting which top-level keys are present in the flat JSON payload and watching whether Slack responds with {"ok":true} or a validation error, the attacker infers the required and optional input fields the workflow is configured to accept (for example, fields like "channel", "user", "severity", or "incident_description").
related_data: Inferred list of JSON field names required for the webhook trigger to be accepted by Slack
Inferred count of inputs (up to 20 variables per Workflow Builder webhook, as documented)
method_steps.notes: While the attacker cannot see what the workflow does with these inputs inside Slack, learning the expected keys and their basic roles (from names like "severity" or "customer_id") reveals the business purpose of the workflow and how deeply Slack is integrated into the victim’s processes.

method_steps.description: The attacker slowly increases invoke frequency (staying near documented limits) and monitors when Slack begins returning rate-limit style responses, confirming the documented one-request-per-second constraint for webhook workflows and learning practical throughput and throttling behavior for this tenant’s automation path.
related_capabilities: Security monitoring, logging, and incident management
related_interfaces: Workflow Builder webhook workflow docs highlighting a one-request-per-second limit – https://slack.com/help/articles/360041352714-Build-a-workflow--Create-a-workflow-that-starts-outside-of-Slack
General Slack API rate-limit guidance – linked from the above help article
related_data: Empirical knowledge of per-webhook rate limits (approximate max requests per second before throttling)
Any rate-limit error payloads or HTTP 429 responses returned by Slack
method_steps.notes: The Help Center explicitly notes that webhook workflows are limited to roughly one request per second; the attacker can confirm this empirically, which informs how aggressively they can probe the endpoint without breaking it or drawing attention.

method_steps.description: Combining the observed endpoint behavior with Slack’s public docs for webhook triggers and Workflow Builder, the attacker concludes that the victim is using a paid Slack plan with workflow apps enabled, has at least one Deno Slack SDK or Workflow Builder automation wired to external systems via webhooks, and is relying on Slack as an operational alerting or integration hub.

related_interfaces: Deno Slack SDK webhook trigger guide – https://docs.slack.dev/tools/deno-slack-sdk/guides/creating-webhook-triggers/
Workflow apps require a paid plan (noted in the Deno webhook trigger guide) – https://docs.slack.dev/tools/deno-slack-sdk/guides/creating-webhook-triggers/
related_data: Knowledge that this Slack tenant is on at least a paid plan that supports workflow apps and external webhook triggers
Awareness that specific business processes (for example, incidents, orders, or alerts, inferred from input field names) are being mediated through Slack workflows
method_steps.notes: This is classic MITRE T1526: the attacker is systematically enumerating what SaaS service capabilities are present (workflow apps, webhook triggers, rate-limiting behavior) inside the compromised tenant.

Security monitoring, logging, and incident management

Inferred schema of the workflow’s expected inputs (set of JSON field names and rough semantics from their names).

preconditions_required: A valid, still-active webhook trigger URL for a workflow or Deno Slack SDK app in the target Slack workspace.
The webhook endpoint must not be further restricted by IP allowlisting in front of Slack that blocks the attacker’s source IP range.
Slack must not have revoked or rotated the specific webhook trigger since the attacker first discovered it.
constraints_encountered: Webhook workflows are limited to approximately one request per second, as documented, which constrains how quickly the attacker can probe combinations of input fields without triggering throttling.
General rate-limiting controls described for Slack APIs may apply to webhook triggers and may result in HTTP 429 or similar responses if the attacker over-probes.

If the victim organization uses IP allowlisting for Slack endpoints, the attacker may only be able to reach the webhook from specific networks or cloud regions (for example, by pivoting through the same infrastructure that originally owned the webhook).

All validation and rate-limit behavior is observable only via coarse-grained HTTP responses; the attacker cannot see Slack’s internal workflow logs or channel messages, limiting the depth of discovery.
evasion_considerations: Keep probe frequency comfortably below the documented one-request-per-second limit and any observed throttling thresholds to avoid generating abnormal error spikes in logs.
Vary JSON payloads gradually and in ways that resemble normal external-integration behavior (for example, realistic field values rather than obvious fuzzing patterns).
Space out tests over time (low-and-slow) so that webhook-related audit events blend into the normal background of legitimate automation traffic.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: By carefully invoking the compromised webhook trigger and observing only Slack’s minimal JSON responses and error codes, the attacker can confirm that the target tenant is running a paid Slack plan with workflow apps and webhook triggers enabled, infer the expected flat JSON schema for at least one production workflow (including the names and rough semantics of required fields), and empirically map Slack’s validation and rate-limiting behavior for that automation path. This is limited, but still reveals how deeply Slack is wired into specific business processes and what automation entry points exist for future abuse.
discovery_vectors.comments: This is the only discovery vector that is realistically achievable from a pure webhook-trigger foothold without any Slack account or token. All higher-value discovery (users, channels, policies, apps) remains blocked because the webhook invoke API exposes only {"ok":true/false} and validation errors, not internal data.

discovery_vectors.technique_name: Cloud Account and Account Discovery via Slack APIs

method_steps.description: Starting from the ability to POST to the compromised webhook trigger, the attacker attempts to induce the backing workflow or Deno Slack SDK app to return information about Slack users (for example, by guessing that certain input fields like "user" or "email" might be echoed or validated in a way that leaks existence).
related_capabilities: Web API for core Slack operations
related_interfaces: Webhook triggers for Deno Slack SDK apps – linked from https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/
related_data: Attacker-supplied JSON fields such as candidate user emails or IDs, if the workflow happens to accept those as inputs.
method_steps.notes: In principle, if a workflow or app were explicitly coded to validate a user or email and then reflect success/failure in the HTTP response, this could become an enumeration channel.

method_steps.description: Because Slack’s documented webhook invoke behavior only returns a generic {"ok":true} on success and validation-style errors (such as parameter_validation_failed) on malformed JSON, with no reflection of internal user or account data, the attacker cannot distinguish between different valid users or enumerate which accounts exist in the workspace.
related_interfaces: Deno Slack SDK webhook trigger invoke behavior – https://docs.slack.dev/tools/deno-slack-sdk/guides/creating-webhook-triggers/#invoke-trigger
related_data: Only coarse-grained success/failure flags for the webhook call itself, not any underlying API or workflow results.
method_steps.notes: Docs show that even successful invocations return {"ok":true} without additional data. There is no evidence that user existence or role information is ever surfaced in this response.

method_steps.description: The attacker considers whether they could reach Slack Web API, Admin APIs, or SCIM endpoints indirectly by abusing the workflow’s internal steps, but without control of the app’s code or visibility into Slack channels, they have no way to see the results of any internal API calls that the workflow might make.
related_capabilities: Web API for core Slack operations
Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
related_data: Potentially rich user and group data that the workflow’s own tokens can access internally but which is never returned to the webhook caller.
method_steps.notes: All of these APIs require OAuth or admin tokens, and their responses go to the app or workflow logic inside Slack (and then on to Slack surfaces), not back to the anonymous webhook invoker.

capabilities_used: Web API for core Slack operations
Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API
interfaces_used: Webhook triggers for Deno Slack SDK apps – linked from https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/
data_accessed: In practice, only boolean success/failure for webhook invocations and generic validation errors are observable; no actual Slack user or account data is returned to the attacker.
preconditions_required: To turn this into a true account-discovery channel, the attacker would need either: (a) a Slack user or bot token with read scopes (users:read, conversations:read, admin/audit scopes, SCIM, etc.), or (b) control over the backing app’s code or infrastructure so that it can send API responses or enumerated user lists to an attacker-controlled endpoint.

The compromised webhook trigger would have to be explicitly coded to use its internal tokens to look up users and then encode those lookup results into the webhook HTTP response, which is not how Slack’s documented webhook invoke path behaves.
constraints_encountered: The attacker has no Slack user account, no OAuth tokens, and no access to the app’s backend or Slack channels, so they cannot see any results from Web API, Admin, SCIM, or Audit Logs calls that the workflow may perform.
Slack’s webhook invoke interface is intentionally limited to acknowledging receipt and basic validation state; it does not expose business data like user profiles, group memberships, or roles.

Enterprise environment controls such as SSO-only authentication, MFA, domain-based registration, and admin approval for new apps further constrain the attacker’s ability to obtain a valid account or over-scoped app token to perform classic Account/Cloud Account Discovery (T1087/T1087.004) from this foothold.

Rate limiting and logging on Slack’s side mean that noisy probing with many candidate user identifiers would be both ineffective (no data returned) and likely to be visible via the Audit Logs API to defenders.
evasion_considerations: Not applicable—this discovery vector is fundamentally blocked by design rather than by detection; stealth tactics do not change the lack of returned data.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: None beyond what was already achievable via the webhook-behavior probing in the Cloud Service Discovery vector. From the webhook-only foothold, the attacker cannot list, validate, or infer Slack user or account inventories.
discovery_vectors.comments: MITRE techniques T1087 (Account Discovery) and T1087.004 (Cloud Account Discovery) are not realistically achievable from this initial access vector. The webhook trigger is effectively a write-only automation entry point from the attacker’s perspective; all user and account data remains inside Slack and is only exposed to authenticated clients and apps with appropriate scopes.

discovery_vectors.technique_name: Permission Groups, Password Policy, and Dashboard-Based Discovery

method_steps.description: From the webhook foothold, the attacker considers whether they can learn about Slack channels, user groups, roles, password policies, or admin/security configuration by abusing the workflow or webhook endpoint (for example, by hoping for descriptive error messages or reflected configuration data).

related_interfaces: Webhook triggers for Deno Slack SDK apps – linked from https://docs.slack.dev/interactivity/
related_data: Only webhook invoke responses ({"ok":true} or validation errors), with no indication of roles, groups, or policies.

method_steps.description: Because the webhook invoke API does not expose any information about which channels, user groups, or roles the backing workflow can act in—and because the attacker cannot see Slack messages, admin consoles, or audit logs—they have no way to infer permission groups, channel structures, or admin assignments.
related_capabilities: Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API

method_steps.description: Similarly, password policy and authentication posture (for example, SSO-only, MFA enforcement, session durations) are managed through Slack’s admin consoles and possibly external IdPs; the webhook trigger API does not surface any of this information, and the attacker cannot reach login or admin endpoints in an authenticated context.
related_capabilities: Authentication and access control (SSO, 2FA, SCIM, EMM)
related_interfaces: Admin security and authentication settings – https://slack.com/enterprise/
related_data: Password/SSO/MFA policy configuration, which is only visible to authenticated admins and not reflected in webhook behavior.
method_steps.notes: MITRE Password Policy Discovery (T1201) and Cloud Service Dashboard-based discovery both assume the attacker can query policy endpoints or view GUI dashboards, which is not the case here.

Audit Logs API and Admin Oversight API

preconditions_required: To perform Permission Groups Discovery (T1069.003), Password Policy Discovery (T1201), or Cloud Service Dashboard-based discovery in Slack, an attacker would need at least one of: (a) a compromised Slack user account (ideally admin) able to log into the workspace and view admin/security settings; (b) a compromised admin or SCIM-capable app token with admin.*, audit, or SCIM scopes; or (c) control of the external IdP or SSO configuration for the tenant.
None of these preconditions are satisfied by merely knowing and invoking a workflow webhook URL; the attacker has no authenticated session, token, or IdP access.
constraints_encountered: The webhook trigger endpoint is intentionally narrow in scope and does not expose any metadata about channels, workspaces, groups, or policies—only success/failure of the trigger invocation.

SSO-only authentication, MFA requirements, domain-based registration, and admin approval for new users and apps (environment constraints) significantly raise the bar for obtaining a real Slack account or privileged app token needed for these discovery techniques.

Admin and SCIM APIs, as well as the admin console and Cloud Service Dashboard-style UIs, are protected by authentication and role-based access controls; they cannot be reached via the unauthenticated webhook invoke path.

Rate limiting and centralized logging would make any brute-force attempts to pivot from the webhook into other endpoints (for example, scanning for additional APIs off the same host) noisy and likely detectable, without yielding useful policy or group information.
evasion_considerations: Not applicable as a practical discovery method—the limitation is architectural (no data returned, no access to dashboards or admin APIs), not purely about detection.
discovery_vectors.information_discovered: None. From the webhook-only foothold, the attacker cannot learn which channels or groups exist, how permissions are structured, who the admins are, or what password/SSO/MFA policies the tenant uses, nor can they access any Slack admin dashboard views.
discovery_vectors.comments: MITRE techniques T1069.003 (Cloud Groups Discovery), T1201 (Password Policy Discovery), and Cloud Service Dashboard–style discovery are all blocked from this starting point. Slack’s design keeps admin consoles and high-privilege APIs behind authenticated sessions and tokens; the webhook invoke surface is effectively a one-bit acknowledgment channel that does not reveal tenant configuration or permission structures.

summary:
From the specific initial access described—control over an exposed Slack workflow or Deno Slack SDK webhook trigger without any Slack account or token—the attacker’s discovery options inside the Slack tenant are extremely limited.

What *is* realistically discoverable:
- By probing the webhook invoke behavior, the attacker can:
  - Confirm that the URL is a live Slack webhook trigger for a workflow app (paid plan required).
  - Infer that the victim uses Workflow Builder or Deno Slack SDK apps with external webhooks for production processes.
  - Learn the flat JSON schema and required keys the workflow expects (input names like "severity" or "incident_description"), revealing the business purpose of that automation.
  - Empirically confirm Slack’s validation and rate-limiting behavior on this trigger (e.g., one-request-per-second constraint, parameter_validation_failed errors for nested JSON).
  This fits MITRE T1526 (Cloud Service Discovery) and gives modest insight into how Slack is integrated into the victim’s environment.

What remains *blocked* from this foothold:
- Account and Cloud Account Discovery (T1087/T1087.004): no way to list or validate Slack users or emails, because webhook responses never include user data and the attacker cannot see Slack channels or app backends.
- Permission Groups/Cloud Groups Discovery (T1069.003): channel structures, user groups, and roles are only exposed via authenticated clients and admin/SCIM/audit APIs, none of which are reachable.
- Password Policy Discovery (T1201) and Cloud Service Dashboard–style discovery: password/SSO/MFA policies and admin/security settings are visible only in admin consoles or via privileged APIs, not via webhook triggers.

Environment constraints such as SSO-only authentication, MFA, domain-based registration, admin approval for apps, and strict rate limiting reinforce these barriers by making it hard for the attacker to upgrade this webhook-only foothold into a real Slack identity or admin token. In short, this initial access vector is impactful for *execution* (it lets the attacker cause workflows to run inside Slack) but yields only very thin discovery: confirmation of one automation entry point and its basic behavior, with no meaningful visibility into users, channels, groups, or tenant security posture.

constraints_encountered: The attacker’s resulting access is explicitly limited to an external Slack account participating in Slack Connect shared channels/DMs; they do not have a first-party account in the target workspace or org.

Domain-Based Registration and SSO-Only Authentication for the target workspace prevent the attacker from registering a local account or logging in via SSO without controlling an approved identity in the target’s IdP.
MFA Required for internal accounts makes direct compromise of an admin account substantially more difficult, limiting realistic dashboard access from this starting point.
IP Allowlisting, if in use for admin access, would further restrict login attempts to specific networks even if credentials were obtained.

discovery_vectors.comments: Using a cloud service dashboard GUI to enumerate resources (as described in the Cloud Service Dashboard technique) is not feasible from this starting point. The attacker only has an external Slack Connect account and cannot access the target’s Slack admin console or broader cloud dashboards without a separate compromise of the organization’s identity infrastructure or admin accounts, which would constitute a different initial access vector.

summary:
From the foothold of an external Slack account in one or more Slack Connect shared channels/DMs, an attacker can perform several realistic Discovery activities without additional compromise of the target organization.

They can conduct Account Discovery by enumerating all visible participants in shared spaces, inspecting profiles, and using search to identify historical and less active internal users. Through careful observation of channel behavior, documentation, workflow messages, and group-like mentions, they can infer permission and role groups (e.g., admins, security, legal, vendor management), approximating Permission Groups Discovery without direct admin/API access.

By watching integration cards, link unfurls, and workflow messages, the attacker can perform Cloud Service Discovery, building a catalog of the third-party SaaS and cloud platforms (e.g., CRM, ticketing, document storage, CI/CD, monitoring, identity) that the target integrates with Slack in the context of the shared engagement. Observing retention behavior, the use of Slack AI and enterprise search, and any shared security/compliance materials allows the attacker to infer aspects of the target’s Slack plan level and governance posture (e.g., presence of SSO/SCIM, advanced retention, legal holds, EKM, and audit logging).  Workflow and process-related artifacts (workflows, canvases, lists, AI-agent summaries) expose how key operational processes function and which teams and tools they involve.

Finally, by leveraging the trusted relationship and standard security questionnaires, the attacker can elicit high-level password and authentication policy information (Password Policy Discovery), clarifying whether Slack is SSO-only, how MFA is enforced, and what password rules apply in connected systems. Environment-wide constraints like SSO-only authentication, domain-based registration, MFA, and admin approvals prevent the attacker from escalating this foothold into direct dashboard or admin-console access, making a full Cloud Service Dashboard-style enumeration infeasible from this initial access. The effective discovery surface is therefore all information that legitimately appears in the shared Slack Connect conversation and its attached artifacts, plus what internal stakeholders are willing to disclose in that context.

summary:
From the foothold of a malicious, consent-phished Slack app with OAuth tokens, an attacker can realistically perform several powerful Discovery techniques entirely via Slack’s documented APIs and surfaces. Using account-discovery style calls, they can enumerate nearly all workspace users and classify likely admins and executives. By abusing conversations and membership APIs, they can reconstruct the effective permission structure of the tenant—mapping public vs private channels, high-sensitivity groups, and how users are grouped into functional teams. Building on this, they can identify which channels are Slack Connect shared channels, derive a graph of external organizations and partner domains, and see which internal teams interact with each partner, effectively mapping the organization’s external collaboration surface.

By mining recent message metadata and app cards in key channels, the attacker can discover which Slack apps, bots, and AI agents (including Agentforce-style agents) are active, and—using public Marketplace information—learn which external SaaS platforms and internal systems those integrations connect to. Separately, by listing files and other content surfaces (canvases, lists) and correlating them with channels, they can locate where large volumes of documents and long-lived documentation reside, identifying data-rich and sensitive areas of the workspace without yet exfiltrating contents.

Environment-level constraints such as MFA, SSO-only login, CAPTCHA, and Admin Approval for apps primarily impacted initial access, not these API-driven discovery steps; the attacker already has valid tokens. The main remaining constraints are Slack’s Web API rate limits, the scopes originally granted to the app, and any IP allowlisting. These can be managed with low-and-slow enumeration and by keeping API usage aligned with the app’s plausible feature set. In contrast, discovery techniques that rely on viewing password policies or interactive cloud service dashboards (such as Slack admin UIs or AWS EKM consoles) are not achievable from this foothold, since app tokens cannot be used to access those dashboards and no human admin credentials have been compromised.

This technique models adversaries logging into a cloud provider’s graphical admin console (for example, Azure or AWS dashboards) to visually explore services and configuration. In this scenario, the attacker only has a stolen Slack OAuth or CLI service token representing an app or service identity, not an authenticated human admin session. Slack’s documented capabilities do not indicate any way to reuse an app token as a browser session credential for the Slack admin UI. SSO-only and MFA requirements for human admins further block console access without valid user credentials and second factors. Therefore, from the current access level, the attacker cannot realistically use Slack’s web admin dashboard as an interactive discovery surface; they are limited to API-based discovery vectors described above.

summary:
From a single stolen Slack OAuth or CLI service token, an attacker can perform extensive Discovery in the Slack environment entirely via legitimate APIs and data flows. At a minimum, typical bot-level scopes allow enumeration of users, bots, channels, and Slack Connect relationships, and observation of workflows and integrations active in channels where the app operates. If the compromised token belongs to a more privileged internal tool (for example, one with SCIM, admin.*, or audit scopes), the attacker can escalate discovery to an org-wide perspective: listing all accounts and permission groups, mapping admins and governance roles, cataloging installed apps, workflows, external integrations, and partner organizations, and reconstructing security posture including retention, exports, EKM usage, and audit/logging coverage.

Environmental controls such as IP Allowlisting and API rate limiting shape how this enumeration must be performed but do not prevent it once a valid token on an allowlisted IP is in hand. MFA, SSO-only authentication, domain-based registration, and CAPTCHA/email-verification requirements mainly protect interactive user logins and do not directly constrain use of already-issued OAuth or CLI tokens. As a result, the principal defenses against these discovery vectors are strong app-governance practices (limiting scopes and approvals), tight control of high-privilege admin and audit integrations, and monitoring for unusual but still-legitimate API usage patterns from app identities.

summary:
Starting from a SCIM/SSO-derived Slack account that the attacker controls (and can map to admin roles via IdP groups), multiple Discovery techniques are realistically achievable:

- As a normal member, the attacker can use Slack’s clients and search to perform **Account Discovery (T1087)**, enumerating visible users, channels, and some external participants based on membership and activity.
- With elevated Workspace/Org Admin rights and control of SCIM, the attacker can perform **Cloud Account Discovery (T1087.004)** by bulk-listing all Slack users via SCIM, admin UIs, Admin APIs, and Audit Logs, obtaining a full inventory of accounts and their activity.
- Using SCIM groups, role mappings, Admin APIs, and channel membership data, the attacker can conduct **Cloud Groups / Permission Groups Discovery (T1069.003/T1069)** to map which groups and roles confer high-value privileges and which users hold them.
- Through Slack’s security and authentication configuration screens and SCIM data, the attacker can execute **Password Policy Discovery (T1201)** in the SaaS sense: confirming SSO-only and MFA enforcement, registration domains, and identifying any weaker or special account categories.
- By examining the app directory, app governance dashboards, Admin APIs, and logs, the attacker can conduct **Cloud Service Discovery (T1526)** focused on Slack integrations, learning which external SaaS platforms are connected, where they operate in Slack, and what scopes they hold.
- Using Slack Connect governance views, Web/Admin APIs, and audit/export data, the attacker can extend **Cloud Service Discovery (T1526)** to map all external organizations and workspaces connected via shared channels and DMs, effectively charting cross-tenant trust relationships.
- Finally, by leveraging Slack’s admin consoles and reporting/export features rather than direct APIs, the attacker can apply **Cloud Service Dashboard (T1538)** to quickly understand overall org configuration, security posture, retention/ EKMs settings, app policies, and Slack Connect controls through low-noise, GUI-based exploration.

Environmental constraints such as SSO-only authentication, MFA required, domain-based registration, IP allowlisting, and rate limiting primarily affected initial access but still shape how discovery is performed. After compromise, the main practical constraints on discovery are API rate limits and app-approval workflows, which can be mitigated through low-and-slow enumeration, reuse of existing privileged apps and tokens, and reliance on built-in admin dashboards and exports. Collectively, these vectors give a determined attacker a rich, multi-faceted understanding of the Slack environment, its users, privilege structures, external connections, and security controls without leaving the Slack application boundary.

preconditions_required: Attacker possesses valid Slack or IdP credentials for a user in the target workspace or Enterprise organization.
If MFA Required is enforced, the attacker must also control or bypass the second factor for that user.

constraints_encountered: MFA Required: blocks simple password-only reuse; attacker must have MFA material or exploit weaknesses in MFA workflows.
SSO-Only Authentication: prevents use of local Slack passwords; attacker must compromise IdP credentials or assertions instead.
IP Allowlisting: disallows logins from arbitrary networks; attacker must pivot through an allowed network path.
Rate Limiting: limits rapid or high-volume login attempts, making brute-force and credential stuffing impractical.
CAPTCHA Protection: hinders automated login attempts; attacker may need manual interaction or CAPTCHA-solving services.
evasion_considerations: Log in from IP ranges, geographies, and time windows consistent with the victim’s normal behavior to blend into audit logs.
Avoid repeated failed logins; only attempt authentication when credentials are believed to be correct to sidestep rate limits and alerts.
Use standard Slack clients and user agents rather than unusual automation frameworks to appear like a normal user session.

summary:
From a stolen Slack user or admin account, an attacker can perform rich Discovery without leaving normal product and admin surfaces.

At the low end, any authenticated user can enumerate a significant portion of the tenant’s identity graph via channels, DMs, Slack Connect spaces, search, and Slack AI (Account Discovery). This reveals many internal users, key participants, and external collaborators but is constrained to the compromised user’s own memberships.

If the compromised account has admin or org-level rights, Discovery becomes much deeper. Using member-management UIs, exports, and (optionally) admin/SCIM APIs, the attacker can build a near-complete inventory of Slack cloud accounts, determine which identities hold high-privilege roles, and map cloud groups and permission groupings (Cloud Account and Cloud Groups). By inspecting authentication and security configuration, they can also understand the tenant’s effective password and authentication posture—SSO-only vs mixed auth, MFA requirements, SCIM provisioning, and related environmental controls (Password Policy Discovery).

Finally, by traversing admin governance pages, app directories, Slack Connect settings, compliance/EKM/export surfaces, and enterprise search/AI features, the attacker can enumerate which Slack services and external SaaS integrations are in use, how apps and external domains are governed, which logging and audit services are enabled, and whether advanced controls like EKM and legal holds are deployed (Cloud Service Discovery). Environmental constraints such as MFA, SSO-only authentication, IP allowlisting, and rate limiting primarily affect new logins and high-volume scripted API use; they do little to restrict in-session, UI-driven reconnaissance, though they do increase the detection surface via extensive logging and Audit Logs records.

Taken together, these vectors give a motivated attacker with valid Slack credentials a comprehensive understanding of who exists in the Slack tenant, how they are grouped and privileged, which cloud services and integrations surround Slack, and how tightly those are governed—all without needing to step outside Slack’s documented capabilities.
